section.title: Source file structure
section.para: A source file consists of,in order:

listitem.para: License or copyright information, if present,

section.para: Exactly one blank line separates each section that is present.

section.title: License or copyright information, if present
section.para: If license or copyright information belongs in a file, it belongs here.

section.title: Package statement
No wildcard imports
section.para: Wildcard imports, static or otherwise,are not used.

section.title: No line-wrapping
section.para: Import statements arenot line-wrapped. The column limit ( ) does not apply to import statements.

section.title: Ordering and spacing
section.para:
Import statements are divided into the following groups, in this order, with each group separated by a single blank line:
All static imports in a single group
org.perfcake imports (only if this source file is in the org.perfcake package space)
Third-party imports, one group per top-level package, in ASCII sort order
for example: com, org, junit, sun
java imports
javax imports

Within a group there are no blank lines, and the imported names appear in ASCII sort order. ( Note: this is not the same as the import statements being in ASCII sort order; the presence of semicolons warps the result.)

section.title: Exactly one top-level class declaration
section.para: Each top-level class resides in a source file of its own.

section.title: Class member ordering
section.para: The ordering of the members of a class can have a great effect on learnability, but there is no single correct recipe for how to do it. Different classes may order their members differently.

What is important is that each class order its members insome logical order, which its maintainer could explain if asked. For example, new methods are not just habitually added to the end of the class, as that would yield "chronological by date added" ordering, which is not a logical ordering.

section.title: Overloads: never split
section.para: When a class has multiple constructors, or multiple methods with the same name, these appear sequentially, with no intervening members.
